Variable Properties

Copy Forward: Manually-entered data for the variable will be repeated in succeeding columns until a user stops the process or changes the value. (Although Customize allows you to do so, you should not set copy forward for device variables.)

Show copy-forward symbol: Determines whether or not a symbol will identify flowsheet data that has been copied forward. This command is only available if the Copy Forward box is checked.

Mathematical Function: Determines the method for representing device data:

l Average: average of all values received during the interval.

l Median: value which has an equal number of values above and below it (during the interval).

l Last Value: last value received during the interval.

For example, the user would see different values in the cell depending on the data type:

DATA RECEIVED

4.0, 5.0, 6.0

LAST VALUE

6.0

AVERAGE

5.0

MEDIAN (50% of the values are below this value and 50% are above)

5.0

Alert LOW and Alert HIGH: Limits that define the levels at which alerts will be triggered.

Artifact LOW and Artifact HIGH: You can configure the application to filter out data generated by electrical or mechanical interference by defining artifact limits. Values outside of the limits are rejected. (Rejected values appear as a blank cell on the flowsheet, a question mark on the Vital Signs bar and as a break in the line on a trend.)

Artifact limits are useful for filtering out zero values when a device is turned off during a session.

Tip: You can use artifact limits to prevent data-entry errors by limiting the values that can be entered for a manual-entry variable.

For example, in neonatal intensive care units, users are accustomed to documenting patient weight in grams. Picis handles all weights in kilograms. The rejection limits for Patient Weight can be set to discard values that are impossible for a newborn.

Format: The format for the data as a number with up to three decimal places, or text. (The options available depend on the variable being configured.)
